parts:
Hi o1. Today we are going to be collecting evidence for a research paper. 

# Ground rules

ABOVE ALL ELSE, if you are unsure about something, or do not have evidence from a web page supporting a claim, do not make a claim. If there is any doubt, there is no doubt.

This is research. SPEND EXTRA TIME above and beyond normal, to collect data carefully and methodically. We don't care about how long it takes, only that your research is accurate and epistemologically grounded. Care and attention to detail second only to the prior rule.

# Definitions

## Tool definition
For our project, a software tool is any discrete piece of software—be it a program, script, or web application—that is developed or substantially modified by researchers to perform specific, research-oriented computational tasks. These tasks must involve active data processing, such as analysis, simulation, visualization, modeling, or automation, where input data is dynamically created, documented, transformed, or interpreted to generate meaningful results. In contrast, products whose primary function is to simply display, store, or promote static datasets—without offering mechanisms for active computational engagement—are excluded. 

In essence, a valid software tool for our purposes is one that not only **supports research in archaeology or historical sciences** but does so by actively collecting and/or processing data rather than merely serving as a generic data repository or static interface.

It is our belief that the tools we have given you meet this criteria, however, if there is an absence of evidence supporting our belief, it is REQUIRED that you inform us of any problems. IF YOU ARE UNSURE, INDICATE IT rather than giving an answer.

# Task

I will be giving you the name or acronym of an archaeology and historical studies-related software tool which dates somewhere from 1995 onwards. 

You must build a well-formed quoted CSV inside a fenced code block with the following columns:
csv
"Tool", "Year", "Source", "URL", "AI Notes"

* Tool is our key column. It is essential to be consistent in tool name, following the input we give you. If there is an issue indicate it in notes.
* Year, year from the web page, article, or source you found, n.d. is a valid entry for "no date"
* Source: Citation or (Domain + Page Title)
* URL, url of the resource. 
* AI notes: any notes, concerns, or uncertainties you have with the data provenance or quality. Do not use HTML citations.

This is a comprehensive and systematic search. For each year, 1995 onwards, we one mention (one line) per source found. Obviously, many of these tools were created after 1995, so we'll want to expand our search by +- 1 year from any date we find. When you find a source, systematically explore adjacent years in your searches.

DO NOT extrapolate dates from sources. ONLY include dates where a source has been published in that year. We will perform all necessary inference, if you include a line for EACH valid source you find. For undated items, indicate "n.d."

This research requires that you be thoughtful, systematic, and take your time. You will likely need to visit EVERY SINGLE PAGE of search results for a given tool. 

To repeat back.

I'm going to give you a list of tools, one by one.
You will search for them.
For every source you find,  we want to record year/n.d., source (citation or title), and url

You MUST build a CSV with the output in your direct response to the deep research process.

Allowed sources: 
* Do try to find it's source code in published version control repos (add a row if they have public code, as the commits will have dates)
* do try to find scholarly literature (each to one row)
* do include blog posts and about pages (each to one row)
* do include any other mentions of the tool (each to one row)

When you respond with data:
RESULTS: Build the CSV of evidence you have found with  ANY mention of that tool in ANY year/n.d. should be on the CSV, regardless of source. Include one line for EACH source you find.

Do you understand?

Yes, I understand your research methodology and careful data collection process.

Please provide the name or acronym of the first archaeology or historical studies-related software tool you would like me to research.

Understood. I will conduct a systematic and comprehensive search for mentions of the tool "Arch-I-Scan." For each source I find, I will extract the year (if available), citation or title, URL, and any AI notes regarding the quality or provenance of the data. If no date is available, I will mark it as "n.d." Additionally, I will check version control repositories, scholarly literature, blog posts, and any other relevant mentions of the tool.

I will let you know once I have compiled the CSV with all available evidence.

content.text:
{"task_violates_safety_guidelines":false,"user_def_doesnt_want_research":false,"response":"Understood. I will conduct a systematic and comprehensive search for mentions of the tool "Arch-I-Scan." For each source I find, I will extract the year (if available), citation or title, URL, and any AI notes regarding the quality or provenance of the data. If no date is available, I will mark it as "n.d." Additionally, I will check version control repositories, scholarly literature, blog posts, and any other relevant mentions of the tool.

I will let you know once I have compiled the CSV with all available evidence.","title":"Comprehensive Evidence Collection for Arch-I-Scan","prompt":"Conduct a comprehensive and systematic search for mentions of the archaeology-related software tool "Arch-I-Scan." 

For each source found, extract the following:
- "Tool": Always "Arch-I-Scan"
- "Year": The year of publication from the source (if no date is available, mark as "n.d.")
- "Source": Citation or webpage title (e.g., "Domain + Page Title")
- "URL": Direct link to the source
- "AI Notes": Any concerns or uncertainties about data provenance or quality.

Requirements:
- Check all relevant sources including scholarly literature, blog posts, about pages, and mentions in public repositories.
- Record one line per source, systematically exploring mentions from each available year since 1995.
- Do not extrapolate dates—only include dates explicitly found in sources.
- Explore systematically across years, ensuring coverage for possible adjacent mentions.

Deliver the findings as a well-formatted quoted CSV inside a fenced code block."}

metadata.async_task_prompt:
Conduct a comprehensive and systematic search for mentions of the archaeology-related software tool "Arch-I-Scan." 

For each source found, extract the following:
- "Tool": Always "Arch-I-Scan"
- "Year": The year of publication from the source (if no date is available, mark as "n.d.")
- "Source": Citation or webpage title (e.g., "Domain + Page Title")
- "URL": Direct link to the source
- "AI Notes": Any concerns or uncertainties about data provenance or quality.

Requirements:
- Check all relevant sources including scholarly literature, blog posts, about pages, and mentions in public repositories.
- Record one line per source, systematically exploring mentions from each available year since 1995.
- Do not extrapolate dates—only include dates explicitly found in sources.
- Explore systematically across years, ensuring coverage for possible adjacent mentions.

Deliver the findings as a well-formatted quoted CSV inside a fenced code block.

parts:
```csv
"Tool","Year","Source","URL","AI Notes"
"Arch-I-Scan","n.d.","le.ac.uk – Arch-I-Scan (University of Leicester project page)","https://le.ac.uk/archaeology/research/new-approaches-to-the-material-world/arch-i-scan","Official project page (no publication date)."
"Arch-I-Scan","2018","intarch.ac.uk – Exploring Automated Pottery Identification [Arch-I-Scan]","https://intarch.ac.uk/journal/issue50/11/index.html","Peer-reviewed journal article (Internet Archaeology issue 50)."
"Arch-I-Scan","2019","gtr.ukri.org – Arch-I-Scan: Automated recording and machine learning for collating Roman ceramic tablewares and investigating eating and drinking practices","https://gtr.ukri.org/projects?ref=AH/T001003/1","Official UKRI Gateway to Research entry (project funded 2019–2023)."
"Arch-I-Scan","2019","youtube.com – Arch-I-Scan - Automated recording for collating Roman artefacts (Univ. of Leicester News Centre)","https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wr9Zksl0D3U","University-produced video (press release feature)."
"Arch-I-Scan","2020","le.ac.uk – Feeding the Machine (Images of Research 2020 entry)","https://le.ac.uk/research/images-of-research/victoria-szafara","University exhibition piece (non–peer-reviewed showcase)."
"Arch-I-Scan","2021","mdpi.com – An Open System for Collection and Automatic Recognition of Pottery through Neural Network Algorithms","https://www.mdpi.com/2571-9408/4/1/8","Peer-reviewed article in Heritage 2021; cites Arch-I-Scan as a reference."
"Arch-I-Scan","2021","vindolanda.com – Scanning Samian pottery during lockdown (guest blog by Arch-I-Scan project)","https://www.vindolanda.com/Blog/scanning-samian-pottery-during-lockdown","Museum blog post by project team (describes Arch-I-Scan volunteer work)."
"Arch-I-Scan","2021","youtube.com – Arch-I-Scan: Roman pottery and machine learning (Dr. Sarah Colley)","https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=isA-APZGTG0","Informational video by project researcher (academic presentation)."
"Arch-I-Scan","2021","archaeology.stanford.edu – ‘Big Data on the Roman Table’: Developing new approaches to recording Roman finewares to investigate their uses","https://archaeology.stanford.edu/events/big-data-roman-table-developing-new-approaches-recording-roman-finewares-investigate-their","Academic lecture announcement (Stanford Archaeology Center Distinguished Lecture, Feb 2021)."
"Arch-I-Scan","2022","jcaa-international.org – The Arch-I-Scan Project: Artificial Intelligence and 3D Simulation for Developing New Approaches to Roman Foodways","https://doi.org/10.5334/jcaa.92","Peer-reviewed journal article (Journal of Computer Applications in Archaeology, vol.5 2022)."
"Arch-I-Scan","2023","archiscannews.wordpress.com – Good luck, Victoria! It won’t be the samian without you.","https://archiscannews.wordpress.com/2023/06/05/good-luck-victoria-it-wont-be-the-samian-without-you/","Official project blog post (farewell message from team member, June 2023)."
"Arch-I-Scan","2023","hal.science – IArch: An AI Tool for Digging Deeper into Archaeological Data","https://hal.science/hal-04384735v1","Conference paper (IEEE ICTAI 2023) mentioning Arch-I-Scan as a case study; not a primary Arch-I-Scan publication."
"Arch-I-Scan","2024","ultralytics.com – AI in Archaeology Paves the Way for New Discoveries","https://www.ultralytics.com/blog/ai-in-archaeology-paves-the-way-for-new-discoveries","Company blog article (Ultralytics, Aug 2024) highlighting Arch-I-Scan as an example; secondary source overview."
```
